Elijah Lee, Independent Financial Advisor at Phillip Securities (Jurong East Lite)Top Contributor (Sep)Level 9. God of WisdomAnswered on 23 Sep 2019Hello there, and as Hariz has pointed out, no, you can't. Even the highest yielding instruments can only pay out 7% tops, and at $7000 a year, that's not going to be enough. I am however not factoring in leverage here, which can increase your yield to 10% or higher, but you would be at the mercy of interest rates.My own passive income off investments is in the 4 figures yearly which I took time to build (and am still building), but ultimately it is a matter of what you find will be a comfortable amount to live off. Some people barely spend $1K a month, some spend $5K. Whatever the amount, the rule of 25 combined with the 4% withdrawal rule gives you the capital you'll need for retirement to work out most of the time. This assumes that your portfolio is grown and invested while you make withdrawals to pay for your needs. Note that such a portfolio is subject to volatility which can impact your withdrawals.So $1K/mth would mean $12K/yr or a $300K portfolio of income assets. Note that I state income assets because you will want to mix it up between bonds, stocks and UTs for diversification.0 comments6

God of WisdomAnswered on 23 Sep 2019If that 100k provides a constant 6% per annum in dividend payout, that's just 6000 a year. I doubt you can survive on 500/mth.If we look at just basic needs, plus the mortgage, and insurance we probably need closer to 2k/mth or 24k/yr.On a 6% income payout, you'll need a 400k portfolio. But then you still lose out on inflation.So if you get a 4% payout portfolio and 2% capital appreciation to hedge against inflation, you'll need a 600k portfolio.0 comments3
